0	http://reuters.com/article/us-california-mylan-nl-idUSKCN11M22C	California governor signs epinephrine bill
column2: blasts Mylan	"

column1: By Dan Levine
| SAN FRANCISCO
SAN FRANCISCO California Governor Jerry Brown on Friday signed a bill to allow businesses across the state to carry epinephrine auto-injectors
column2: but sharply admonished drugmaker Mylan NL over its recent price increases.Mylan has been widely criticized
column3: including by U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton
column4: for raising the price of EpiPens
column5: which are carried by people with life-threatening allergies.The company
column7: recently raised the list price for a pair of EpiPen auto-injectors to $600. The price has been rising from a cost of about $100 in 2008. A probe into EpiPen pricing by a U.S. Senate subcommittee was announced on Sept. 7.Brown's decision on Friday highlights the predicament facing allergy advocates
column8: who strongly support epinephrine access legislation but have criticized Mylan's pricing.

column1: Over two dozen U.S. states have passed laws similar to California's authorizing businesses to stock epinephrine
column2: according to advocacy group Food Allergy Research & Education. Brown said he was signing the bill because EpiPens save lives
column3: but that he strongly objected to Mylan's pricing.

column1: State government cannot stop unconscionable price increases
column2: but it can shed light on such rapacious corporate behavior
column3: Brown said in a statement.A Mylan representative could not immediately be reached for comment.

column1: EpiPen
column2: which has annual sales of about $1 billion
column3: delivers a potentially life-saving dose of epinephrine by injection into the thigh to counter dangerous allergic reactions
column4: including to peanuts and bee stings. Mylan owns 94 percent of the market for such auto-injected devices.    In response to the furor over pricing
column5: Mylan last month said it would sell its own generic version of EpiPen for $300. (Reporting by Dan Levine; Editing by Alan Crosby)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-toomey-idUSKCN11M0WQ	In Pennsylvania Senate race
column2: unfamiliar battle lines on gun rights	"

column1: By Joseph Ax
| PHILADELPHIA
PHILADELPHIA As he seeks re-election to his U.S. Senate seat this November
column2: Pennsylvania's Pat Toomey can make an unusual claim. He is the sole Republican nationwide running with the endorsement of top U.S. gun control advocates Gabby Giffords and Michael Bloomberg.That pair of endorsements could give the first-term senator an edge over Democratic challenger Katie McGinty
column3: a former environmental official in the White House and the Pennsylvania governor's office. The race is one of a handful of close contests on Nov. 8 that could determine whether Republicans
column4: currently with a 54-46 majority
column5: maintain control of the Senate.Both candidates are targeting educated moderate voters
column7: many of whom may be turned off by the rhetoric of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump
column8: according to political analysts in Pennsylvania.McGinty
column9: who calls her support of gun control measures stronger than Toomey's
column10: is working hard to dismiss his endorsements from Giffords and Bloomberg
column11: and has touted her own endorsement by a Pennsylvania anti-gun violence group.Giffords
column12: considered a hero by many gun control advocates
column13: is a Democratic former U.S. congresswoman from Arizona who survived being shot in a 2011 assassination attempt and has become an activist for gun restrictions. Bloomberg is the billionaire former New York City mayor who considered a run for the presidency this year and
column15: has focused much of his energy on gun control.McGinty has called Toomey's commitment to gun safety ""paper thin"" and notes that the Republican incumbent received an ""A"" rating from the influential National Rifle Association gun rights lobbying group during his first Senate run in 2010.The issue of gun rights is potent in a nation where the right to ""keep and bear arms"" is enshrined in Constitution's Second Amendment. The NRA opposes candidates who support gun control efforts including restricting the types of firearms people can own or expanding background checks required for gun buyers. Many Republicans side with the NRA
column16: while many Democrats support gun control.Opinion polls show Toomey's race as virtually tied
column17: even as Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton leads Trump by several percentage points in a state that has voted Democratic in the past six presidential contests
column18: starting in 1992.Pennsylvania is home both to rural communities where hunting is a popular pastime and big cities including Philadelphia and Pittsburgh where crime and gun violence are major concerns. Shifting attitudes on guns in the state have emboldened both parties in Pennsylvania to distance themselves from the NRA's stance opposing almost any effort to restrict gun rights.The state's law mandating background checks for private handgun sales already goes beyond federal law
column20: director of the Franklin & Marshall College Poll in Lancaster

column1: Pennsylvania has a very substantial hunting and fishing culture
column2: Madonna said. ""But hunters aren't opposed to that.""'HARD THING TO DO'

column1: Toomey's position on guns sets him apart from most of his Republican U.S. Senate counterparts
column2: as he tries to attract moderates while keeping conservative voters in his column.In a telephone interview
column3: Toomey said the Giffords and Bloomberg endorsements recognized ""that what I did was a very hard thing to do politically."" He also emphasized his belief that most gun owners share his position.

column1: I'm a strong Second Amendment supporter
column2: Toomey said. ""I see no contradiction between that support and insisting on background checks
column3: so that people who've got no right to the Second Amendment because they're dangerous criminals or they're dangerously mentally ill or they're terrorists
column4: should be denied a firearm any way we can.""Giffords has also endorsed Illinois Senator Mark Kirk
column5: another Republican running for re-election
column6: though Bloomberg has not weighed in on that race.In an email
column7: McGinty told Reuters Toomey is ""no moderate"" when it comes to gun violence.""Time and again
column8: he has sided with the gun lobby instead of doing what's right to keep communities safe
column9: McGinty said. ""Pat Toomey has completely run away from legislation to expand background checks
column10: since it failed to pass the Senate three years ago.""Toomey made headlines in 2013 following an elementary school massacre in Newtown
column12: when he and Democratic Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia introduced legislation to expand background checks for gun buyers nationwide.

column1: That legislation
column2: fiercely opposed by the NRA
column3: failed in the Senate
column4: but Toomey gained praise from Democrats for bucking the majority of his party.He voted for a similar bill after the mass shooting last year in San Bernardino
column5: California
column6: and supported Republican-backed legislation in Congress this year following the Orlando nightclub shooting to restrict access to firearms for people on official ""terrorism watch lists.""McGinty backed a stricter Democratic-backed version. None of the measures passed.McGinty
column7: who called Toomey's gun control positions weak
column8: favors more sweeping restrictions such as bans on military-style ""assault weapons"" and high-capacity ammunition clips that Toomey opposes.In a recent television ad
column9: McGinty used a clip of Toomey telling voters this summer that he had a ""perfect record"" with the NRA. The NRA has not yet released ratings or issued an endorsement in the race.Toomey called McGinty a ""political opportunist"" and again pointed to his support from Giffords and Bloomberg.""The idea that somehow they've all got it wrong and Katie McGinty
column11: has it right is just laughable
column12: he said.(This story corrects Senator Mark Kirk's home state to Illinois from Ohio in 15th paragraph.) (Reporting by Joseph Ax; Editing by Scott Malone and Will Dunham)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-vote-precincts-insight-idUSKCN11M0WY	Polling places become battleground in U.S. voting rights fight	"
By John Whitesides
| LINCOLN PARK
column2: Ga.

column1: LINCOLN PARK
column2: Ga. Louis Brooks
column4: has walked to cast a vote at his neighborhood polling place in Georgia's predominantly black Lincoln Park neighborhood for five decades. But not this year.Brooks says he will not vote in the presidential election for the first time he can remember after local officials moved the polling station more than 2 miles (3 km) away as part of a plan to cut the number of voting sites in Upson County.""I can't get there. I can't drive
column5: and it's too far to walk
column7: a black retired mill worker and long-time Democratic Party supporter. He said he does not know how to vote by mail and doesn't know anyone who can give him a ride.A Reuters survey found local governments in nearly a dozen
column8: mostly Republican-dominated counties in Georgia have adopted plans to reduce the number of voting stations
column9: citing cost savings and efficiency.In seven of those counties
column12: comprised at least a quarter of the population
column13: and in several counties the changes will disproportionately affect black voters. At least three other counties in Georgia dropped consolidation plans under public pressure.While polling place cutbacks are on the rise across the country
column15: the South's history of racial discrimination has made the region a focus of concern for voting rights advocates.Activists see the voting place reductions as another front in the fight over Republican-sponsored statewide voting laws such as stricter ID requirements that disproportionately affect minority and poorer voters who tend to vote for the Democratic Party.Several of these have recently been struck down by courts that ruled they were designed to hinder minority voting. ""There is a history in those states of using different strategies to cut voting in minority communities
column17: senior counsel at the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People Legal Defense and Education Fund.""Hogwash
column19: chairman of the Upson County Board of Elections
column20: denying that race was a factor in his board's decision.""Nobody is trying to keep anybody from voting
column22: adding that officials would send a ballot to the home of anyone who needed it. He said the cut in polling sites from nine to four was designed to increase efficiency by closing low-turnout sites
column24: 000.The Nov. 8 election will be the first presidential contest since the Supreme Court ruled in 2013 that Georgia and all or parts of 14 other states with a history of racial discrimination no longer need federal approval for election law changes like polling place consolidations.Since the court ruling
column26: more than two dozen local governments in eight of those states have implemented new cuts in polling places. Two thirds of those were met with public opposition.

column1: Four of the states - Arizona
column2: Georgia
column3: Florida and North Carolina - could be election battlegrounds in the fight for the White House and control of the U.S. Senate.

column1: IMPACT CAN BE DISASTROUS""
This is part of the story of voting in the South
column2: said Willie Williams
column3: a black small business owner from Daphne
column4: Alabama
column5: where polling stations were cut to two from five during last month's municipal elections over the objections of black voters.Williams
column6: who still keeps his father's receipt for his poll tax - the tax some blacks in the South had to pay to qualify to vote before civil rights laws in the 1960s eliminated it - says the reduction was ""just another tool in the tool kit for shaving off minority votes.""Daphne city officials denied any racial motivation
column7: saying the changes were meant to improve safety and create better access and parking for voters.Still
column9: a research director at the liberal group Democracy North Carolina
column10: says the effects of such cutbacks can be wide ranging. ""The elections boards aren't lying when they say some of these locations have low turnout and it makes better administrative sense to close them - but the impact can be disastrous.""

column1: Numerous academic studies have found people are less likely to vote the farther they must travel and the longer they must wait in line
column2: which becomes more likely with fewer voting sites.""Some of these changes individually may affect only a small number of voters
column3: but in the aggregate across the country it will be a very large number of voters
column4: said Danielle Lang
column5: voting rights counsel at the Campaign Legal Center
column6: a Washington-based voting rights and campaign finance group.The issue gained prominence in a March primary in Arizona's Maricopa County
column7: where more than 30 percent of residents are Hispanic. A decision to slash polling places left voters in lines for up to five hours. Republican county officials said they misjudged turnout.CONSOLIDATIONS

column1: Georgia has been an epicenter for efforts to reduce polling places since the Supreme Court decision. And in that state
column2: which has not backed a Democrat in a presidential election since 1992
column3: polls show Republican Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton in a close battle for the presidency that could be decided by turnout of minority voters.

column1: If you want to restrict voter turnout in minority and disadvantaged communities
column2: a good way is to move a polling place somewhere they can't get to
column3: said Stacey Abrams
column4: Democratic leader in the Georgia state legislature.Hans von Spakovsky
column5: a senior legal fellow at the conservative Heritage Foundation
column6: said race was being unfairly inserted into the debate on polling place changes.""It's election officials making adjustments based on the changing ways people are voting
column8: using voter registration lists for 2012 and 2016
column9: found at least two Georgia counties where the changes disproportionately affect blacks.A consolidation plan in Macon-Bibb County closed six polling places in black-majority neighborhoods
column10: and only two in white majority areas. McDuffie County's decision to eliminate three polling places means two-thirds of the county's black voters
column11: and one-third of its white voters
column12: will now vote in one location.Other changes have had little impact on minority voters. In Georgia's Lumpkin County
column14: where blacks are just 2 percent of the population
column15: officials consolidated seven polling locations into one to make the county compliant with federal disability laws.Voting rights groups in several states have tried to form patchwork networks to track the changes
column17: and then fight back where necessary with threats of lawsuits
column18: petition drives or complaints to federal officials.In Upson County
column20: the elections board dropped a proposal to close a polling site in heavily black Salem
column22: after residents pointed out the hardship of traveling an extra 10 miles (16 km) or more.But the Lincoln Park site
column23: which had just 230 voters cast a ballot in person on Election Day 2012
column24: was more easily combined with a polling place in the center of the nearby town of Thomaston
column26: the only African-American member of the elections board in Upson County and the only one to vote against the voting site closures
column27: said she knew it meant some Lincoln Park residents would not be able to vote.""They walk to the store
column28: they walk to church - when you don't have transportation to get to something like this
column29: it makes you not want to do it
column30: you just throw your hands up
column31: she said.  (Additional reporting by Andy Sullivan in Washington; Editing by Jason Szep and Ross Colvin)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-khan-idUSKCN11M07Q	London's Muslim mayor backs Clinton for U.S. president	"
By Dave McKinney
| CHICAGO
CHICAGO London's first Muslim mayor
column2: Sadiq Khan
column3: voiced support for Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton on Thursday
column4: warning that anti-Muslim views like those espoused by Republican Donald Trump ""plays into the hands"" of Islamic State.During a stop in Chicago on his first visit to the United States

column6: Khan told reporters following a speech to more than 250 academics
column7: diplomats and business people.""As the father of two daughters
column8: I think the message it sends when the most powerful politician in the world is a woman is phenomenal
column11: who as mayor of London is arguably one the most influential member of his faith in western Europe.

column1: Immediately after taking office in May

column3: deriding his plan as ""ignorant.""During his roughly 45-minute speech before the Chicago Council on Global Affairs

column5: such as tightening Muslim immigration into the United States.

column1: I think to suggest somehow that Muslims aren't welcome in the U.S.A.

column4: refugees or visitors. (Reporting by Dave McKinney; Editing by Michael Perry)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-obama-idUSKCN11M1P4	Obama has 'better things to do' than comment on birther issue	"

WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama on Friday said he had better things to do than comment on Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's announcement about the so-called birther question over Obama's citizenship. ""I'm shocked that a question like that would come up at a time when we've got so many other things to do - well
column2: I'm not that shocked actually
column3: Obama told reporters.    ""I was pretty confident about where I was born. I think most people were as well
column4: Obama told reporters in the Oval Office
column5: where he was meeting about a trade deal with Asia.

column1: Trump plans to address Obama's citizenship on Friday

column1: My hope would be that the presidential election reflects more serious issues than that

6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-economy-idUSKCN11L27G	Trump scales back tax cuts in new economic plan	"
By Emily Stephenson and Alana Wise
(The September 15 story was refiled to correct to $4.4 trillion tax cut
column2: not cost of plan in third paragraph)By Emily Stephenson and Alana WiseRepublican presidential nominee Donald Trump unveiled a plan on Thursday for $4.4 trillion in tax cuts
column3: offering less generous tax breaks than his original $10 trillion plan but proposing to cut the current top rate for the wealthiest taxpayers.Trump's proposal
column4: which he detailed in a speech in New York
column5: would reduce the top individual rate to 33 percent from the current 39.6 percent. It would raise the standard deduction and cap itemized deductions
column6: which he said would reduce tax loopholes. Trump said his plan would not add to the federal deficit.Trump said the $4.4 trillion tax cut would actually cost less
column8: under a mechanism known as dynamic scoring
column9: which assumes that tax cuts will lead to faster growth
column10: which in turn would allow at least some of the tax breaks to pay for themselves.Trump also offered a ""Penny Plan"" for cutting federal spending. He said he would shrink government programs outside of defense by 1 percent each year. But entitlement programs such as Social Security and Medicare would be shielded from any cuts.The original tax plan laid out by the New York businessman last September was criticized by Democrats and Republicans alike for its costly price tag. Democrat Hillary Clinton
column11: who will face Trump in the Nov. 8 election
column12: denounced it as catering to the very wealthy and ignoring the working class.Some economists also questioned the assumptions underpinning the plan he outlined on Thursday.

column1: In his speech to the Economic Club of New York
column2: Trump predicted his updated package to reduce taxes
column3: curb government regulation and take a tougher stance on negotiating trade agreements would produce annual economic growth of 3.5 percent.""Everything that is broken today can be fixed
column4: and every failure can be turned into a great success
column5: Trump said.He added the plan would create 25 million jobs over a decade. Trump set 4 percent as a goal for economic growth
column6: in a message reminiscent of that of his former Republican rival Jeb Bush.

column1: The U.S. economy last achieved 4 percent growth during the administration of Democratic President Bill Clinton in the 1990s. The economy grew 2.4 percent last year.'IT DOESN'T SQUARE'
Oren Cass
column2: a fellow at the Manhattan Institute and domestic policy director of Republican Mitt Romney's 2012 presidential bid
column3: said the plan for 1 percent cuts in some programs would not be enough to pay for Trump's proposals.

column1: It doesn't square
column2: Cass said. ""The penny plan is an idea that's been out there for a while
column3: but it does touch entitlement spending as well.""Maya MacGuineas
column4: president of the bipartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget
column5: welcomed the scaling back of Trump's original tax-cut proposals but said the plan would still leave the country on an unsustainable budget path.""He's moving in the right direction by pursuing a less costly tax plan and identifying some spending cuts to help pay for it. But the plan appears to rely on rosy assumptions and murky policy changes
column6: she said in a statement.Other groups have predicted more adverse effects from Trump's policies. Earlier this week
column7: global economic research firm Oxford Economics projected the U.S. economy could be $1 trillion smaller than otherwise expected in 2021 if Trump becomes president. (Reporting by Emily Stephenson in New York and Alana Wise in Washington; Additional reporting by Steve Holland in Washington; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-tax-idUSKCN11L1TW	U.S. tax avoidance clampdown a potential headache for Apple	"
By Jason Lange
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Apple Inc and other U.S. multinationals will face new curbs on tax loopholes under a rule imposed by Washington on Thursday
column2: part of a scramble among governments worldwide to bolster their corporate tax bases.Acting shortly after a European Union grab for billions of dollars in back taxes from Apple
column3: the U.S. Treasury said it was tightening restrictions on companies' use of foreign tax credits to reduce what they owe in U.S. taxes.""We are closing another tax loophole that contributes to the erosion of our tax base
column4: Treasury Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy Mark Mazur said in a statement. The fight for multinational tax revenues escalated on Aug. 30 when the EU ruled Ireland was giving improper state aid to Apple in the form of a deal for low taxes. The EU ordered Apple to pay Ireland 13 billion euros ($14.6 billion) in back taxes
column5: prompting U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew to express concern the EU ruling could undermine the U.S. tax base.Analysts have speculated whether Apple would be able to cut its U.S. tax bill by claiming foreign tax credits for its extra tax bill in Ireland.

column1: Under normal circumstances
column2: U.S. companies can reduce the taxes they owe the U.S. government by the value of the tax credits they claim for taxes paid abroad on foreign profits. No U.S. tax is due on those profits until they are brought into the United States
column3: or repatriated.The new rule will prevent companies faced with back tax bills from ""splitting
column4: a strategy that allows companies to bring foreign tax credits into the United States without repatriating the income from which they were derived.

column1: Apple had no comment on Treasury's tax notice. The technology giant is not the only U.S. company in the crosshairs of EU state aid investigations.Starbucks Corp has been ordered to pay up to 30 million euros ($33 million) to the Dutch state
column2: while Amazon.com Inc and McDonald's Corp are under investigation by the EU's executive arm.The new rule was likely to ratchet up transatlantic tensions over corporate taxes while eliminating one more strategy U.S. companies can use to cushion the blow from increasingly aggressive EU tax collection efforts.

column1: The tax notice specifically cited European Union state aid investigations as a risk to U.S. revenues.The Treasury had no comment on whether its notice would have an impact on Apple directly
column2: but a spokesperson said the notice applies to all companies required by a foreign government to pay additional taxes
column3: including those hit by state-aid cases. (Reporting by Jason Lange; Editing by Meredith Mazzilli and Howard Goller)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-global-forex-tax-idUSKCN11L2CS	Apple tax row raises $2.1 trillion question for forex traders	"
By Patrick Graham
| LONDON
LONDON If the fallout from a huge EU tax bill handed to Apple includes a push to encourage U.S. firms to bring more profits onshore
column2: recent history suggests the impact for the dollar can only be positive. U.S. presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton have both promised to take steps that would encourage major companies to bring home more of the estimated $2.1 trillion in as-yet-untaxed income they hold offshore. That amount compares to the roughly $300 billion brought back in 2005 under George W. Bush's Homeland Investment Act (HIA)
column3: which slashed the effective tax rate on repatriated funds from 35 percent to 5.25 percent. As this graphic tmsnrt.rs/2cymacf shows
column4: the dollar rose around 10 percent that year against both the euro and the basket of currencies that measures its broader strength
column5: even if analysts still argue about how far that move was driven by the tax scheme. Against the yen in the same period it rose 15 percent.  ""The fact that U.S. corporations hold larger cash piles offshore than ever is a reason why a new repatriation tax holiday could be a bigger boost for the dollar than in 2005
column6: Morgan Stanley said in a report in July. ""Though we stress the headline number for offshore earnings overstates the unhedged foreign currency amount
column7: which is relevant for FX markets.""

column1: EURO HAVENS
The U.S. bank also lays out tables of data that it says show where the most money has accumulated. Some 56 percent of funds have been reinvested in Europe
column2: including 12 and 19 percent in Ireland and the Netherlands respectively
column3: compared to 7 percent each in traditional tax havens like Bermuda or Singapore.But a trawl through the accounts of the biggest U.S. corporate holders of funds oversees suggests that much of these funds are held in dollars - meaning little or no money would have to be exchanged from
column4: say
column5: euros into dollars.

column1: Apple
column2: for example
column3: said last year its $186.9 billion in cash and cash equivalents held by foreign subsidiaries were ""generally based in U.S. dollar-denominated holdings"". As of June 30
column4: 92 percent of Microsoft's $113 billion was in U.S. government and agency securities
column5: corporate debt or mortgage-backed securities.Given that in 2004 only around $300 billion of an estimated $500 billion in untaxed offshore funds were brought home
column6: that suggests many firms' repatriations might not involve any foreign exchange at all.

column1: Citigroup chief currency strategist Steven Englander said that even the simple return of dollars to the United States is likely to have a big impact on the currency. ""The dollar money would come back into U.S. equity markets quicker than the non-dollar cash
column2: he said. ""It would be very good for U.S. equity markets and would probably attract foreign money into the U.S.
column3: pushing up U.S. yields in a risk-friendly way. It would be very dollar-positive.""Englander
column4: who also studied the issue in detail the last time a new repatriation act was being talked up in 2011
column5: says the figure for the amount currently being held abroad is something like $2.5 trillion. Converting even a small share of that huge sum from foreign currencies could be significant.""No one knows the currency breakdown for sure. 80 percent in dollars sounds reasonable. So 20 percent of $2.5 trillion is a big number
column6: he added. (Additional reporting by Jamie McGeever; Graphic by Nigel Stephenson; Editing by Catherine Evans)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-wells-fargo-accounts-senate-clawbacks-idUSKCN11M091	U.S. lawmakers ask Wells about taking back bonuses linked to scam case	"

WASHINGTON Five Democratic U.S. Senators have asked Wells Fargo if it plans to take back bonuses and other compensation to executives linked to the 2 million phony bank accounts that employees created to meet sales quotas.The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and other regulators announced last week that they had reached a $185 million settlement with the bank over the scam.""...We write to ask whether the Board of Directors will invoke Wells Fargo's clawback authority to recover any of the compensation the company has provided to its senior executives
column2: including Carrie Tolstedt
column3: the former senior executive vice president of community banking
column4: they wrote in a letter dated Thursday and released on Friday.The five - Massachusetts' Elizabeth Warren
column5: Ohio's Sherrod Brown
column8: and Oregon's Jeff Merkley - said Wells Fargo has cause to claw back money under a policy it instituted after the 2007-09 financial crisis.

column1: These clawback provisions are designed to prevent exactly what happened with Ms. Toldstedt: Shareholders and consumers bearing the burden of bank misconduct while senior executives walk away with multimillion-dollar awards based on what the company later finds out are fraudulent practices
column2: they wrote.

column1: Toldstedt led the bank division running the incentive program that pushed the employees to create fake accounts under real customers' names
column2: often hurting those customers' credit scores
column3: and received more than $20 million in annual bonuses between 2010 and 2015
column4: they wrote.Wells CEO John Stumpf will testify on Tuesday before the Banking Committee
column5: where Brown is the most senior Democrat.

column1: (Reporting by Lisa Lambert; Editing by Cynthia Osterman)"
